rev.comment: I think the word "related" is better than "tied", since some services are not "tied" (in a negative sense like "vendor lock-in") to Ubuntu
rev.diff:
Line 27: Line 27:
Ubuntu is designed primarily for desktop use, although [[netbook]] and [[Server (computing)|server]] editions exist as well.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/desktop/get-ubuntu |title=Get Ubuntu |publisher=ubuntu.com |accessdate=17 October 2010}}</ref> Web statistics suggest that Ubuntu's share of [[Linux desktop]] usage is about 50%,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://statowl.com/operating_system_market_share_by_os_version.php?1=1&timeframe=last_6&interval=month&chart_id=4&fltr_br=&fltr_os=&fltr_se=&fltr_cn=&limit%5B%5D=linux |title=Operating System Version Usage |publisher=statowl.com |accessdate=29 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://stats.wikimedia.org/wikimedia/squids/SquidReportOperatingSystems.htm |title=Wikimedia Visitor Log Analysis Report - Operating Systems |publisher=Wikimedia |accessdate=11 December 2009}}</ref> and indicate upward-trending usage as a web server.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://trends.builtwith.com/Server/Ubuntu|title=Ubuntu Usage Statistics |publisher=builtwith.com |accessdate=19 April 2010}}</ref> Ubuntu holds an estimated global usage of more than 12 million users,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.muktware.com/a/3/2/29/2010/531?page=0,0 |title=Exclusive Interview: Ubuntu Is The Number 1 Desktop OS |publisher=Muktware |date=2010-11-29 |accessdate=2011-05-27}}</ref> and it is considered by [[DistroWatch]] to be the most popular distribution of Linux.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://distrowatch.com/stats.php?section=popularity|title=Linux Distributions - Facts and Figures|publisher=distrowatch.com|accessdate=26 April 2011}}</ref>
Ubuntu is designed primarily for desktop use, although [[netbook]] and [[Server (computing)|server]] editions exist as well.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/desktop/get-ubuntu |title=Get Ubuntu |publisher=ubuntu.com |accessdate=17 October 2010}}</ref> Web statistics suggest that Ubuntu's share of [[Linux desktop]] usage is about 50%,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://statowl.com/operating_system_market_share_by_os_version.php?1=1&timeframe=last_6&interval=month&chart_id=4&fltr_br=&fltr_os=&fltr_se=&fltr_cn=&limit%5B%5D=linux |title=Operating System Version Usage |publisher=statowl.com |accessdate=29 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://stats.wikimedia.org/wikimedia/squids/SquidReportOperatingSystems.htm |title=Wikimedia Visitor Log Analysis Report - Operating Systems |publisher=Wikimedia |accessdate=11 December 2009}}</ref> and indicate upward-trending usage as a web server.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://trends.builtwith.com/Server/Ubuntu|title=Ubuntu Usage Statistics |publisher=builtwith.com |accessdate=19 April 2010}}</ref> Ubuntu holds an estimated global usage of more than 12 million users,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.muktware.com/a/3/2/29/2010/531?page=0,0 |title=Exclusive Interview: Ubuntu Is The Number 1 Desktop OS |publisher=Muktware |date=2010-11-29 |accessdate=2011-05-27}}</ref> and it is considered by [[DistroWatch]] to be the most popular distribution of Linux.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://distrowatch.com/stats.php?section=popularity|title=Linux Distributions - Facts and Figures|publisher=distrowatch.com|accessdate=26 April 2011}}</ref>
â
Ubuntu is sponsored by the UK-based company [[Canonical Ltd.]], owned by [[South Africa]]n entrepreneur [[Mark Shuttleworth]]. Canonical generates revenue by selling [[technical support]] and services tied to Ubuntu, while the operating system itself is entirely free of charge.
+
Ubuntu is sponsored by the UK-based company [[Canonical Ltd.]], owned by [[South Africa]]n entrepreneur [[Mark Shuttleworth]]. Canonical generates revenue by selling [[technical support]] and services related to Ubuntu, while the operating system itself is entirely free of charge.
==History and development process==
==History and development process==
